Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This is one of the best value hotels in New York, well located 2 minutes from Wall St, large comfortable rooms, friendly staff and great breakfast, the only fault is that the bathrooms are a little past their prime and could do with some renovation, overall would recommend this hotel to business and tourist guests

Great cozy hotel in a great location in fidi, close to the seaport. We had a very quiet and enjoyable stay here. Since there weren't a lot of guests, we got upgraded to a suite - very impressive! Bed was comfortable and shower functioned. I would definitely stay here again!

The service was great my room was always cleaned and also had great hospitality they made it feel like home I always had fresh stuff in my room and I would definitely come back to the hotel again !!!!

We booked this hotel at the last second due to our original accommodations falling through. We did not know what to expect as we were not acquainted with the Eurostars brand. I must say we were pleasantly surprised. The hotel was located right smack in the middle of the financial district, which made it a lively atmosphere during the week (dead on the weekend), with vendors, foodtrucks and people galore. There is good shopping and eateries nearby and the pier is right there for those interested. Parking was a big issue, but hello, we are in NYC. If you found street parking at night (which we did every night in front of the hotel) we were good until morning when we had to feed the meter. Trust me the cops would be there waiting to write that ticket.The hotel......upon entering, it was clean and very inviting. They did a good job decorating the lobby to make guests feel welcomed. The lobby is small, so not really a place for socializing. The rooms were spacious and clean. Our room had 2 double beds and a sofa that converted into a bed. There were 5 of us that stayed in there and apart from us having to share one bathroom, it was pretty comfortable for us all. The bathroom left more to be desired from. It was a bit shabby and needed some TLC. It looked as if the bathroom was in the middle of being renovated and they forgot and booked that room. However, it was clean enough to not gross anyone out. The room came outfitted with a coffee maker, microwave, small fridge, desk, chair, alarm clock/radio and television with the relevant channels. Overall, it was a good stay here and I would stay here again if I ever had the opportunity.....hopefully the bathroom would be in better shape by then :-)

I stayed at this hotel for 8 nights last week. I was visiting my office in the Wall Street area and my company paid for me to stay here. Overall, not a bad stay, but this place does need some improvements. Here are my thoughts:The staff: Overall, excellent!! I received great service from their front desk staff and housekeeping. I enjoyed interacting with them all and by the time I left I felt like I had a new set of friends in the city.The rooms: HUGE! My room was gigantic. Just a couple of things, though. It needs updating. The fixtures in the bathroom were worn and breaking. My shower head was loose and didn't have any pressure. The toilet seat was about to fall off all week and was never fixed. The cheap fixtures (bathroom cabinet, bed table) were badly damaged and chipped. The floor was also warped and some of the flooring was peeling up.HUGE PET PEEVE: NO HDTV!!! What kind of a hotel doesn't have and HDTV these days? The limited channels and lack of HD really ticked me off. The channels were fuzzy most of the time and were barely watchable. This MUST be fixed! SECOND PET PEEVE: No temperature control. The A/C only goes to 68. For most people, this would be fine. But, I prefer it to be around 60 degrees at night for a comfortable sleep. Couple of bonuses: FREE wifi and the location (right off of Wall St). Overall, this place got the job done. With a few major improvements, it could easily have earned a five star rating from me. I think next time I'll stay at the Holiday Inn express across the street for the free breakfast.

The hotel is very well positioned, downtown in wall street. Close to ferry piers, Underground, battery parks and so onVery nice and silent rooms (we stayed at 8th floor)The only complaint is about breakfast, not really international and quite poorThe hotel staff was still kind and promptly available for any inquiries ...I would come back there !!

This is one hotel i think should not be classified as a 4 star as there is nothing that amounts to that. Me and my friend checked in for a night as i had an early flight to Dallas and was so disappointed, The beds are horrible, the rooms looked like a studio apartment and nothing like most 4 star hotels i have used. The bathroom was okay and noise levels not bad as its behind main road. Hotel just let me down and pictures need updating to show current situation otherwise it is misleading.

I'm surprised the average rating is 3 1/2 stars for this place. It's a dump. I found the staff to be unfriendly - even going out of their way to not engage. I had to change rooms because the outlet in the bathroom was caved in - very dangerous. It's dirty, dark, depressing and not worth the money. Stay somewhere else.

I chose this hotel to be "adventurous" and deviated from my usual. A mistake. While the staff was nice and helpful, the hotel is well designed but is aging and is poorly maintained. There is something wrong when the letter "H" of Hotel at the entrance is crooked. This is by far no 4 stars hotel. The one-ply toilet paper speaks volumes about it. That was sadWhile the rooms are spacious and clean, there were no carpets on mine and the only things in there were a bed and one single chair. It looked cavernous. The walls have scuff marks and some of the things in the room were dusty. One lamp was burnt out. The wooden frame of the sink was horribly warped and discolored due to moisture (as well as most of the hotel notes around the room). The bar was closed indefinitely. And the breakfast was the saddest thing I have ever seen. Only a small tray with bacon of dubious quality, some stripes of ham some of cheese, no eggs. The hallways are somber and the carpet of the hallway had moisture marks.Sad is the only word that comes to mind about this hotel. It could be so much better.

We had 3 rooms on various floors of the hotel and they were all very different. Definitely not your traditional hotel rooms. Check-in was pretty easy with no issues. However, taking the elevator was an issue. They have only two and were pretty slow especially when one of them wasn't working properly. We had two double beds in a pretty large room with a couch, small wall mounted flat screen tv, refrigerator and big desk. Complaints about the room included a constantly flowing toilet, a phone system that couldn't connect to one of our other rooms, and a thermostat that couldn't regulate the heat very well. Other than that, location was decent in the Wall Street area.

Located in a great spot on Wall Street. Has a studio fit out, not a typical hotel room. Very comfy bed. It was an excellent place to stay on our trip to the city. It's within a good walking distance to some goof restaurants and to the fairy.

This is the second time we have stayed here and we will definitely return. When we arrived, my husband mentioned we'd stayed before and we were given the room we stayed in before. Which we thought was lovely. The room was a bit dated and not one of the refurbished ones but was very spacious and warm, which was vital as the weather was atrocious. The carpets in the hallways are in desperate need of replacing, they absolutely reek of stale cigarettes and the housekeeping in the room was a bit haphazard. Sometimes the towels would be replaced immediately and at others we'd get one clean one and then another would turn up hours later. This is the only hotel we've stayed at where we had to request that the toilet roll be refilled. Despite all the negatives I've put here, we will return. The location is excellent and the reception staff cannot be faulted.

The pictures of this hotel are a bit deceiving. Though the room is large, the hotel needs help. The carpeting and furniture are worn out. The television is very small. The air conditioning only goes down to 68. The staff is not the most helpful. Hangers were broken. Towels were dingy. Overall, in order to make this a good hotel, they need to invest a little bit.

Our daughter recently had surgery in NYC and we took her to the Eurostars Wall Street to recover afterwards. The room was huge and the staff did all they could to make us comfortable. The beds were comfortable and it was nice to have a small refrigerator and microwave as well as a couch which is unheard of in most NYC rooms. There are plenty of places nearby to get anything you need and lots of tourist attractions nearby. Definitely recommend!

We found large, renovated rooms in an old hotel. Its location closest to wall-street. Best location to visit lower Manhatten, Brooklyn-Bridge, WTC, Ground Zero, Staten Island Ferry and so on by foot, but also Metro nearby. Friendly staff, clean rooms, furniture a little "worn-out".

Polite and considerate staff and very well appointed room. Very clean with many amenities in the bathroom to make you comfortable. The breakfast was extra ($10) but more than continental with eggs and sausage. Many choices of bagels, toast and pastries and juices and fruit. We only stayed one night but nice location near South St. Seaport and bus stop. Good choice near Wall St.

Nice staff, great price, clean room! I give it a 5*..Something are updated and something are not.but I didn't really care about that it was a nice CLEAN place to lay my HEAD. The staff was nice and helpful. They helped us to find a place to park our car, where to eat and when we checked out we could check our bag for FREE!! And pick them up whenever. I would most definitely stay here again.

This is an average hotel, far from 4 stars. At first glance it looks nice, but a closer look shows that it is cheaply designed and appointed. Dark wood shelves and barroom cabinet looks very nice but you soon notice that it is not real wood and much closer to cardboard. The bathroom sink is a bowl type where the sink sits on to of a cabinet. The cabinet holding it was water dammaged and falling apart. The furnature also looked rich and well built but is all cracking, peeling and torn. The bath itself is really odd. The tub has a half glass wall that does not enclose the shower. You have to stand directly under the shower to shower. The shower head does not have a normal shower setting. It is more like standing under the tub faucet. The breakfast is inconsistent. Some days it is good, someday they seem to forget to put items out, or just don't care. I was given an upgrade and if it was upgraded I would hate to see the standard. The good part is the place was clean, the staff friendly, and it was close to where I needed to be.

First, let's talk about the positives. The room was decent size, it was inexpensive, and the location was great. Now, the rest of the story. While I didn't expect luxury, I expected some comfort. Instead, the room was extremely uncomfortable. The bad was unnaturally high and uncomfortable, the furniture appeared to be from the yard sale, there was no place to sit down, there were no power plugs by the bed, so there is no way to plug in the lamp, or the alarm clock. TV was broken. I regretted choosing this hotel.

review_body: The room we had was spacious (for NYC) and spotless. Only 2 short blocks from the subway and only one block away from a 24-hour diner. The harbor is directly behind the hotel. HELPFUL HINT---The hotel is in the Financial District so free street parking is available from 7pm Friday through 7am Monday. I arrived on a Friday afternoon, parked in a lot for 3 hours ($15.00), moved my car promptly at 7pm into an open street spot directly behind hotel on a well-lit street, kept it there until Monday at 7am, and then moved it back to the lot for another 3 hours ($15.00). Total cost for parking in NYC for a weekend-$30.00. I will be staying at this hotel again.

I have been staying at this place regularly for about a year now. The manager, Marta Bueno and her staff including Ivan, Lobsang and others make my stays comfortable and enjoyable. They are attentive to detail and always willing to help in any way they can. The rooms are clean and comfortable, conveniently located to Wall St. and many downtown Manhattan attractions and restaurants.

Room was unclean. Front desk staff has a bad attitude. After asking for wake up call, staff called my room half hour later than I requested. Other than a great location (Wall St.), I will not recommend.

Great location; quiet financial district after 6:00 PM. Two blocks from the 2 or the 3 subway lines; 4 blocks from the 4 or the 5. A 24 hr Duane Reade right around the corner on Water St. A stone's throw to battery park, and a 15 - 20 minute walk to Chinatown. Hotel staff helpful and friendly. My standard room was very large (esp. for NYC) . High ceilings with a couch in front of a large screen TV. The queen size bed was like a studio bed. The mattress a little thin and hard but comfortable for most. My only complaint was the shower. There was only a half-pane of stationary glass in the shower which made the first few minutes in the shower a little cold as the rear half of the shower was exposed. Some areas of the hotel had clearly seen better days. But if you don't mind worn carpets in the hallways (I never sleep in the hallway unless I had too much to drink) and a "used" bathroom vanity, it is a decent hotel.

The staff are great but the hotel sucks everything is breaking walls are nasty and the manager is always stuck to a computer i over heard one of the staff talking about how she needs a better job bc this hotel was drying her up she say her back was always hurt but i dont blame her bc my husband try picking up the mattress to get something under the bed and them mattress were heavy not only that they dont get pay much which i dont understand why when they killing them self.. the cleaniness in the room was great they give it there all other than that the hotel is all crapped up bc of all the paint needed the sink falling apart.. and the mini bar things are expensive a thing of m&m 4.00 buck when i can go to the store and pay 1.00 buck... but managing needs to get off her be-hide and work with everyone, but staff are great loved them. they made feel home.

review_body: Compared to the previous reviewers, we were going in, with almost the expectation to go someplace else. We read reviews that were either hit or miss. We were blown away at how nice the place was. We got an upgrade (unexpected) and the room was great. Nice size with a little living area. The shower head was a little low for my taste, but that was really my only complaint. The service was good... the location was really close to the helicopter ride and close to taxis. Great room and we really enjoyed staying there.

I say 'once' purposefully. On the face of it, this looks like a chic hotel. I arrived quite late at night after a long day travelling and first impressions were of a spacious room. I'd been met with a warm welcome and told that I'd been given a free upgrade. So far so good. However, after tossing and turning all night because of the street noise (it's a block away from the West Road - very noisy) and the bright lights coming into the room because the curtains didn't close in the middle, I found that in the cold light of day the room wasn't as good as I had first thought. The duvet was very badly stained and it made me feel unclean to think that I'd slept under it. The bathroom furniture has been badly damaged by water and is warped and the laminate coating is splitting. I complained about the duvet and was met with a 'what happened?' response. What happened was that a dirty duvet was left on my bed!Next morning, the w.c. blocked and was unusable. I went back to the room at lunch time to ensure that it'd been cleared and, thankfully it had. The dripping sink tap had also been replaced, which I hadn't complained about, so that was a bonus. Additionally, the paintwork in the room is badly scuffed and marked and the tv only had good reception on a couple of channels. I handed in a feedback card 5 days ago, requesting that someone made contact with me. So far, no one has, so I am voicing my opinions in this way. This was once a lovely hotel, I'm sure. Right now, though, it needs a renovation and some tlc.I've given it a '2' because it is in a good location if you want to be in the FiDi and my complaints were dealt with promptly, however, they are complaints that should never have arisen in the first place. I also used the free wifi which cut out a few times, but on the whole was reliable.I can't comment on the restaurant or food because I didn't have inclusive breakfast and wasn't prepared to pay $15 for it.Sadly, my overwhelming memory of this hotel is a dirty duvet and a blocked wc; not good memories.

Room's are not clean. Wifi connectivity is terrible. Their website advertises pretty and chic rooms but that's just simply not the case. It's sheer, false advertisement. The floors are dirty and the place is old-looking.

My husband and I stayed at Eurostar Wall Street Friday through Monday. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Upgraded us to a suite and let us check in early. Location was great, close to subway stations and Brooklyn Bridge. Our room was clean and large. Could use some minor updates, but great for the money.

There should be a provision for negative rating also. As this place doesn't even deserve 1 star. On my recent visit to NY with my baby and husband,we had to make short notice reservation for a night. Trusting the reviews we went for it as its in a very good location..But that is the only good thing about it.I think my graduation hostel room was better than the one i stayed in.-old worn out furniture.-Dirty floor(There were even candy wrappers on floor when we checked in)-Accidentlly i touched one of the shelves in the room and found my hand covered in dust.-Mattress was very uncomfortable and the sheets were tucked in so tight as if they didn't want us to use them.-I even experienced a bug bite.- Vintage air conditioner.Am i missing something else? It was so unhygienic that i didn't even wash my baby's bottle over there.No matter how good a deal you are getting,,its not worth it.

Staff was very helpful, they gave us all the information we needed to know Manhattan.Facilities are in pretty good shape, it has some details like the furniture in the restroom which it was deteriorated with moisture, nevertheless, bed is good to get a good sleep.Style and decoration are good.The bad thing is that restaurant has nothing descent to eat, breakfast is bad, we had breakfast at starbucks everyday. No room service either.Internet service very good, no extra cost, desktop to work on the laptop very good and spacious.Location is good blocks away from several subway stations.

Since this hotel is located in the financial district and not in the typical places for tourists I thought that the standard was higher than average. I was wrong. Neither was the price lower or the quality better than the average Manhattan Hotels I've stayed at before. Too bad the air condition units makes a lot of sound, because the street is pretty quite compared to most Manhattan streets.

We (me, my wife and son) had booked another hotel, Comfort Inn Central Park West on August 27, 2014. The rep at Hotels.Com said in NYC $200/night was the cheapest and Comfort Inn was the best deal. We were shocked when we checked into Comfort Inn. Small, dingy, smelly and overall just horrible! So, we ended up searching for another hotel out of desperation. Then, we found this little jam of a hotel: Eurostars Wall Street from Booking.Com. The price was $150 per night, so actually cheaper than Comfort Inn. Way nicer, with spacious one bedroom, a kitchen (a refrigerator, microwave and dishwasher) and comfortable interior. It's more of a full-service apartment than a hotel room, given its layout. Staff at the front desk were incredibly helpful and kind. The free laptop and a printer at the business center with free gourmet coffee constantly flowing came in handy for the paperwork I had to do. No breakfast was included, though. Internet speed was too slow so I had to use my own portable Wi-Fi. But, what a location! A bloc away from the shoreline: Seaport. You can take the cruise, jog around and spend time at the nearby Seaport shopping area. I loved Dim Sum at a Chinese restaurant within 10 minutes of walking distance. If you love the sauna like I do, you have to check out Wall Street Bath & Sauna. Of course, like the name, you got Wall Street within a stone's throw and all the subway stations within short walking distance. We are from L.A. where "no body walks" but I loved walking around here. Exhilarating! Sea of people and the constant humming of sounds! Everything you need and want naturally appear out of nowhere around this hotel. New York is just great. It is teeming with people, life and all-day non-stop attractions. This hotel, at such a nice price, can provide you with a comfortable stay, especially given its extremely convenient location. I would recommend this hotel to anyone, really. I'll come back to stay here next time I'm in NYC.

The hotel location is very good. In business area you can easily walk to ground zero and Century 21 (for the shopping addicts). There are several places to eat and some nice bars in the area.You're not far from the subway lines 2,3,J, Z, 4 and 5 (5-10 mins walk) and several cabs drive walter street all day long even at night.The hotel itself is very nice froùm the outside and the lobby is great. Roomes are clean and confortable, plus they look nice but definately not as nice as a 4 stars room should be.Some materials are a bit old, the bathroom is ok but small and the shower was a bit rusty.The corridors are small and smell strange, plus carpets are old and a bit stained.They lack a decent breakfast (which I guess should be free) so we had to take breakfast outside.Finally we enjoyed our stay in this hotel that I recommend, especially since the staff was very kind and helpful but I guess there are some minor details to fix so it matches his 4 stars status.

Great hotel in central down town Manhattan, very close to wall street.Great service by the staff. Lots of info if you wanna see downtown attraction sea port by sea land or air.Breakfast is not included. It's a real American breakfast and it's everyday the same. There's bread, fresh fruits, cereals/muesli, yogurt, scrambled eggs and sausages. You can get orange juice or pineapple juice. There is also fresh coffee or thee.There is free WiFi all over the hotel grounds and rooms. My room was very spacious with a full kitchen.If you are staying in room all day, be aware that a staff will come door to door to ask if you consumed from the mini bar. There is a business center located at the reception with a laptop and a laser printer if you need to do some printing or surf the web. There is even some snacks, thee or coffee if you need some(all free).I had a great stay nice people and comfortable room. If I go back to NYC I'm certainly stay again.

Will located hotel, near attractions sites, and transportations is easy to different locations at NY city, room is wide but with below avarage furniture. Breakfast is very restricted in quality. There was no bill capten. Staff are from different cultures and sometimes uncooperative

I would qualify this hotel as a well kept secret. Great value for the location room and bar/restaurant. Staff very friendly and helpful, easy in and out. Location is great by the East River and Seaport district, another couple of blocks and you are in Chinatown. You can do all of downtown with ease, anywhere in Manhattan is easy to get to via subway, no hassles. Because you are on the east side getting to JFK or La Guardia via taxi is very easy.Plenty of options within walking distance, "bike station" next door........

The rooms are poorly appointed....broken light fixtures...worn out bathrooms...poorly maintained facility. The staff gave me keys to an occupied room but never apologized because he (David) thought it was someone else's fault! No concierge help to speak of....Definitely won't stay here next time.

Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: For starters it's 82 degrees out and our air conditioner does not work. Supposedly they sent a man to fix it while it was gone and it did not work still. The beds are hard and uncomfortable and there is mildew and water damage in the bathroom and the ceilings. The service was mediocre at best and that's an overstatement. The bathroom door opened into the closet door and it got extremely difficult and frustrating after the first half hour. I wouldn't recommend staying here especially since there are other, nicer, and most importantly cheaper hotels in this area. I truly enjoyed my stay at your Hotel Eurostars, everyone was friendly and helpful, hotel is within walking distance to all events, once we parked and checked in, we went down to waterway and the water taxi was a wonderful way to travel.

After checking in to the hotel, I was immediately disappointed seeing a 4 star hotel being so dirty. The toilet flush didnt work - and you can imagine what happend. review_body: Just got back and was pleasantly surprised by this hotel. I booked through Hotwire and was not given the name or exact location until my card was processed. After being assigned to this hotel in the Wall Street area I was concerned about being so far from my preferred area. Anyhow, I did email Eurostar in advance requesting a room with 2 beds. Upon arrival, I was granted my request and more! We were assigned to a huge room on the 6th floor with an additional couch and two closets! The room was very clean and had 3 big beautiful windows. The room also had a microwave and minifridge. Front desk and maid service was good and efficient. We managed getting around to all our activities and sites by using the nearby subway system.

Let me see if I can paint you a picture. I roll my luggage down Wall St, and hang a left onto Front Street. As I get close to where I thought Eurostars is, I see an awning that says "Hotel Wall Street". There was a flag over it, but it was wound up (probably in shame). I finally noticed the faint writing on the window that said "Eurostars". I went in the door, and noticed that there are stairs up to the lobby (not the most accessible, but that is the least of their problems). I got 1/2 way up the stairs before, what I assume was the bellhop, got up from the couch and 1/2 pretended to offer help. Now let me say that I stayed here before a long time ago. The bed was so hard, it was like sleeping on the floor. I had to ask for extra pillows, and they ended up bringing me another comforter, which I doubled and slept on top of. Well, this time I saw that they had "updated" the hotel, which I hoped had included the beds. Nope. The next morning I mentioned how hard the beds were. The guy at the front desk said "really?" like he had never heard that before. Really insulting. He then said "All of our beds are the same, there shouldn't be a problem." Then, in a complete contradiction he offered to move me to another room. I then asked the obvious question "If all the beds are the same, how will that help?" I asked him to send up extra pillows, so I could sleep on them. He said he would. That night, no pillows. Whatever. I was in town for work, and didn't have time to deal with crappy hotel service. Now let's take a minute to notice some of the other lacking aspects of the hotel room. There was no guide for the tv channels, despite the idea that most guests are from out of town and don't know what the channels are. There was no hotel book with basic information, like numbers to reach the concierge, restaurant hours, gym information, etc. Nothing. Not one piece of hotel information in the room. The next morning, I was in the bathroom, and look down. Next to my feet is a parasite looking bug swarming around the room. I kill it, notice another one and kill that. On my way out the door, I tell the front office that I killed 2 gross bugs in my bathroom. He remembers me at the guest he sent pillows up to. I let him know I never got them. He looks confused, refers to a clip board, and says he will take care of the bug issue, and be sure pillows are sent up. That night - still no pillows. The next morning, two more bugs, and I notice a dark kinky hair on the floor of the bathroom. I really don't understand why people need to come in and "clean" my room. I mean they move my toothbrush, invariably putting germs on it for no reason. They move my things around, and leave the bugs and their hair on the floor. The last day, I found one more of those nasty bugs. I had about had it. This time, I grabbed a cup and trapped it. Then I caught a little video of it moving around in the cup, to illustrate the disgusting-ness of this hotel stay. (sorry can't post link) I showed it to the two guys at the front desk, when I was checking out. They looked dumbfounded. Didn't offer to refund any part of my stay and just let me leave without attempting to fix any part of the stay. When they asked if I would stay there again I said "I think not."

The room was clean, nicely decorated and located perfectly to all the sights in lower Manhattan, parking garages and the Metro system. We would definitely stay here again and highly recommend this hotel for the money!!

When you stand at the front door and look up, do a 180-degree sweep, all of a sudden you feel that you're a LEGO man!I stayed for 1-night, it was freezing cold and snowy. It's not exactly the prime area for all the entertainment in NYC. However, over the spring/summer months - it's minutes by foot to the piers that heads out of town, with a park in the area too. Those who are staying in the area for more than a few days, with the time to enjoy NYC, no harm in staying a bit further from all the lights. Less noise, less traffic, yet it's about 20-minutes to all the action.The rooms are huge (at least the one I stayed-in). Seems like it's more of an apartment. However, no hot water in the shower - but there were in the wash basin, strange.Nothing fancy either. Seems that the furniture looks more like from IKEA put together by the handyman and some soon to fall apart though.

We booked two queens non-refundable via Expedia for a two night stay. We were two couples and a baby. When we checked in, we were told we would be upgraded to a suite, but only had one queen in the room with a sofa bed. By "suite", they meant a separate kitchen with a faulty light that flashed incessantly and two microwaves. The "sofa bed" was not even made and we were not provided sheets. Not to mention, it was hardly the size of a single bed, so how the hotel expected two adults to sleep in it is beyond me. When we complained we were told because we booked via Expedia, our room type was not guaranteed, and seeing as they were fully booked and had had some recent water damage to some of the rooms (bla bla bla) there was nothing that could be done. But they did provide us with 2 cots which were more comfortable (and larger) than the sofa bed. The cots had sheets, but no comforters. The queen bed also did not have a comforter (just sheets). When we requested comforters, we were told there weren't any left, but were kindly provided 5 additional sheets!!! Furthermore, the queen bed was as hard as the floor. At that point, we wanted our money back to go stay in another hotel, but we were told by front desk staff there was no manager until Monday morning, conveniently the day we were checking out, so again - no refund was possible. The next morning we spoke to Claudia at the front desk (honestly, the best thing about this hotel - they are lucky to have her). Claudia provided us with another room with 2 queens (which apparently was not available the night before, even though we were able to change rooms at 9:30am before housekeeping had started) and comforters. She also comped breakfast (mediocre) and drinks at the bar. There were other guests complaining of the same situation as we were the next morning, and they also had booked with Expedia. My husband and I stayed at this hotel August 2010 and were satisfied the first time, enough to return. Unfortunately, the last stay left a sour taste in our mouths so we won't be back a third time. If you plan on booking this hotel, do so directly with the hotel, and not Expedia, even though when we checked, Expedia was 150$ cheaper per night.

While Eurostars Wall Street is by no means a "bad" hotel, it is difficult to grasp just how it managed to earn its 3½ star distinction on TripAdvisor. Hotels of superior quality in the Financial District have similar ratings, while having earned those ratings with their wide variety of appealing and functional amenities. Unfortunately, our high hopes for Eurostars Wall Street - which we based primarily on the photographs made readily available online - went largely unmet.Last week, a friend and I decided to travel from California to the Big Apple to take in a concert. Having never been to New York, I was pretty oblivious when it came to choosing the right hotel accommodations in my price range. After doing exhaustive research on my own - which yielded mixed results - I gave up and let Hotwire do the picking for me, which matched me up with EuroStars Wall Street. Despite reading some reviews that made me more than apprehensive, I tried to stay upbeat concerning its potential and promise.Upon arrival, the jovial front desk staff greeted us warmly and supplied us with our room keys, which expedited the overall check-in process. While in the lobby, it becomes immediately clear that photographs online obscure certain details of the facilities, most notably the size of the hotel itself. While this does not reflect on the integrity of the place, we were certainly taken back by it. Perhaps our own inclination to believe everything in New York is big, with its larger-than-life buildings and sky-high monuments, played a role in our ignorant befuddlement..? Your guess is as good as mine.Maybe it was their off-season, or it's possible we came and went at odd times, but the hotel itself seemed to be a virtual ghost town. During our three night stay, we only ever saw three to four guests congregated in the lobby, or waiting to check in/out. While in our room, we only ever heard one other guest coming and going on our floor. The bar and restaurant - touted by some TripAdvisor reviewers as being of exemplary quality - was positively deserted. Again, who knows why this was the case but, whatever it was, we found it strange.Once in the elevators, the presence of a biting cigarette odor quickly became apparent, and the source became even clearer once we stepped out of the elevator and into the narrow hallways. It would seem that smoking and non-smoking rooms share floors, and that residual smell from the smoking rooms bleeds out into the halls. I'm not really picky, nor would I bother to complain to the front desk about something so seemingly inconsequential, but it's worth noting in this review for the sake of travelers boasting sensitive noses, pesky allergies, or a militant disdain towards the stench of cigarette smoke.In hindsight, I've had a difficult time figuring out just what about our room fell short. Despite some sort of chemical or ever-present water stains to the bathroom counter top, my room was quite clean. However, I have to throw my weight behind some of the previous reviews that make note of the low quality carpeting. It was a peculiar choice for a hotel that postures itself as somewhat high-end, no doubt in an effort to keep in step with competition in a predominantly upscale business district.Stylistically, the rooms come together nicely. A minimalist theme takes shape, with emphasis placed on solid black-and-whites in furniture, curtains, and bathroom fixtures. A comfortable futon-style bed, as well as a very modern bathroom sink immediately catch the eye. However, upon closer inspection, wear-and-tear and shoddy workmanship from previous remodels becomes visible; including, but not limited to, inexplicable dead spots under the carpeting. Holes in the floor seem to have been carpeted over and left entirely unfilled. I would imagine this sort of thing could pose a bit of an injury concern for older guest which, in turn, should raise liability concerns for the hotel owners. Issues like the aforementioned are unfortunate, since the overarching theme of the hotel - at least in theory - is spectacular. It simply has a ways to go before it can be placed in the same stratum as its high priced pseudo-contemporaries. Located within short walking distance of the subway, as well as right down the street from Seaport for myriad shopping and dining options, Eurostars Wall Street is tucked away in arguably one of the cleanest and safest parts of New York City. If you're bringing children along, this is a wonderful neighborhood (in New York City terms) that you don't have to be wrought with worry over. McDonald's, Subway, Starbucks and Duane Reade (a CVS or Walgreens-type drug store, for my fellow ignorant west coast folk) are only a few minutes walking distance away. Cab rides from JFK to Eurostars Wall Street are a flat rate of $45 (tip not included) if you request non-toll roads.If you're looking for a no-frills, bare bones sort of hotel at a quality price, in what is traditionally considered an exorbitantly priced area, this hotel should certainly appeal to you. It has seen better days, and has its share of dinginess and stains on carpets and walls, but you will get a quiet nights sleep (save for the all-too-familiar New York City street noise). If you require the finer things in life, or expect access to things like a gym or pool, you should consider looking elsewhere. Again, this hotel is not bad by any means. It's very ambitious but, if anything, it's simply a tad underwhelming for the price tag.

This is a decent NYC hotel. The lobby is quaint and the rooms were modern and clean. The lounge furniture (leather chairs) were a bit worn. The carpet would not be my choice. The hotel is in a good location downtown within walking distance of the Seaport.

If its your first time in New York, i will recommend you to stay in another part of Manhattan. The location is a bit boring since its in the financial district. A hotel closer to Times square or around 34th street would be more fun because everything is in walking distance. The hotel was fine though, clean, good service and the rooms were okay! Not 4 star okay though!

This place advertises as a 4 star property. NEVER in a million years would this be 4 star quality. I have had better experiences at a Holiday Inn. First off, my company paid 2300 bucks for 8 nights. Right when you walk in the lobby, you can tell its cheap. They offer you a glass of wine and talk it all up but you can just look at the floor, walls, etc and tell its all cheap crap. Then the elevator buttons have smear marks all over the buttons... elevator is all dingy and wobbly and dirty.. food on the floor.. dirt, etc. Once you get to your room, you are immediately NOT impressed with the rooms amenities. Small tv, HARD beads, hand/window air units, the ironing board.. god I will never get over it. Totally stained, ripped and the iron itself was like a 10 dollar walmart iron. The mirrors and "fancy decor" all IKEA. Bathrooms? Horrible caulking, cheap flooring, damaged and dingy doors, chips out of the paint everywhere, etc. Bathrooms in the "lounge" ... no hand soap.. REALLY, no soap. I called down to ask if they had a better room because the bed was hard the guy was RUDE and said "uh no, and its all like that in every room". No real service, no real amenities, and a dirty dingy hotel. D O N O T waste 2-3 hundred a night on this dump. Lets just say their website is a photo shop dreamland...it all looks good but in person, YOU DONT LOOK LIKE YOUR PICS!

I thought it was a great hotel! The rooms were huge and very comfortable. The staff at the front desk was wonderful. They were willing to help with anything. One even ran out to try to help us flag a cab. The maids were very friendly and helpful. I thought it was a great hotel in a nice area with very reasonable prices. I will definitely use this hotel again.

This Hotel was perfect for "bike New York " , close to the bike expo and the ferry landing at the finish. The hotel clerks were very accomadative , the rooms are larger than any hotel in the city for this price. My friends and I will be here next year.

The rooms were nice, the location great.We stayed for the Bike Tour NY. I can't say enough about the help at the front desk.All desk clerks went out of their way to help no matter what the question. They even offered help at various times before we asked. Marc was especially good, always going the extra mile. The rooms were nice and clean. We were upgraded to a suite by the front desk since we arrived before check in time.
What a terrible hotel. Old, shabby rooms, dead service and ambiance. Priced like a mid price hotel, but everything else is like a shabby student dive. Only good point is the location.

I think a lot of people have covered majority of the issues that I have with this hotel so I'll try not to go on. I was staying in room 408, which was right at the back, the windows were looking out into the middle of the hotel so it was dark in the room all the time.Also being in this room there was some sort of generator outside which made too much noise for my liking, with the windows shut I could still hear a murmur. The carpet was not really carpet but I walked around bare foot for a while and my feet were black (my carpet at home doesnt do that). The showerhead had limescale on it and was not very powerful which has to be a first for one of the hotels that I've stayed in. The bath should've been white and wasnt it looked like someone had done a poor job of cleaning it. Also my complimentary shower gel wasnt replaced on a daily basis... I dont understand this when it should've been.There was a fridge in the room which was quite noisy as well and I'm a light sleeper not great. I put the ironing board up on the first day and it was put away but on the second day when I came back from work the ironing board wasnt put away, I would normally do it myself but I didnt know how to with this ironing board...It was also a bit chilly in this room and the blanket was quite thin, I didnt complain on the first 4 days but when I did complain I was told the heater was central and had to be turned on the next day so I was given an extra blanket then when I went the next day I was told that it wouldnt be turned on and they gave me a little electric heater (which I did ask for the night before but was told that the hotel didnt have one).My work had paid for this hotel so I guess it was not such a great loss for me but I would rather pay a little extra and stay at the Andaz not far from here, it would make such a big difference...On a positive note, the hotel staff were really friendly and always ready to assist!

In the financial district, and just a walk across to the South Street Ferry, this place proved to be a perfect place to start our trip! We were a trio, and so we got a penthouse that looks into the office building next door, quite a unique experience though. The room was clean and updated, and the in-room internet was great for us to do any last minute research! We were also able to get into action immediately as we walked to South Street Ferry for a view of the Brooklyn Bridge, and the South Ferry for shops like Coach, Abercrombie & Fitch, Gap and cheap musical tickets! The staff were very friendly and helpful, and while we checked out two days later to go to Washington, they helped us to store our luggage, although we were not coming back to stay anymore! A pleasant experience that i would recommend!!!

New York City is famous for expensive dives and mediocre rooms at insane prices. Eurostars is one of a small group of relatively inexpensive hotels such as The Pod and Club Quarters that really give good value for the money. Like all NYC hotels, it's a little run down around the edges, but it's clean and relatively spacious, everything works, and the service is good. There's a nice lounge in the lobby for breakfast and late evening drinks. The wireless is free and works well. There laptop and printer in the lobby are available to print boarding passes free. Getting around on a weekend can be a real bear if Subway work is being done - it's 2 blocks away from a station that tends to get closed pretty often. However, there's a lot to do and a lot of places to eat inexpensively (and well) nearby if you don't feel like walking to the next open station. There's a convenient drug store about a block away. Don't feel shy about picking this one - it made for a relaxing business trip.

This hotel is certainly one of the least expensive hotels in the Financial District / Seaport area. I should know since my company has put up many employees here over the years and the prices are consistently among the lowest in the area.This weekend was my first stay here and I can say that it was a pleasant one. The checkin/checkout process was smooth, the room was clean and the services were good. My only problem was with a very loud guest across the hall - one call to the front desk and they were quiet for the rest of the night.I'd stay here again without a second thought.

It's surrounded by scaffolding and on a one-way street; my taxi driver had to call his dispatcher to get directions. But it's one block from a jogging path along the river, which I appreciated. Everything was very clean.I was upgraded to a one-bedroom corner suite with full kitchen. Since it's a older building the rooms were sizable and there were lovely tall windows and I believe 10- or 11-foot ceilings.Unusually sunny for a hotel room. I could hear the elevator and street noise, but that's true of many hotels and the bedroom was buffered from the hallway by the kitchen and bathroom. The living room had a two-seater leather couch and club chair, which I don't find comfortable against skin, a desk with shelving, books and magazines, and a wall-mounted HDTV. There were a moderate number of channels, a couple of which dropped in and out. The room could have used reading lamps by the couch and chair, and if the couch were longer it would have been more comfortable for stretching out. The free Wifi was reliable on a weekend but dropped in and out on weekdays. But I appreciated the size and tall ceilings and windows. There is a hall closet and the room was large enough to have guests or clients (although limited seating). Phone was in this room.I agree with others that the platform bed with thin mattress should be replaced, but I don't mind somewhat firm mattresses and it didn't prevent me sleeping. Plenty of pillows and an extra blanket. Neither of the bedside reading lamps worked (unless I failed to figure out the switches) and it was late so I didn't bother to ask for help. But there was a sizable bedroom closet with organizers (shelves, drawers) tucked inside it. There was a wall-mounted TV in the bedroom but no second phone. No bedside tables (no room).Ironing board, iron and full-length mirror. Nice bathroom with shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, sewing kit, shoe shine cloth and shower cap. Plenty of towels and soap. Sufficient shower pressure; toilet handle had to be held down to flush. Fancy glass bowl sink but not much space to lay down your things -- but there are shelves over the toilet.They served a complementary full breakfast in the bar, beginning at 7am. Scrambled (powder) eggs, meats, toast and other breads/pastries, yogurt, fruit, juice and coffee and tea. A great timesaver and hot food is always appreciated.The staff was very friendly and responsive, dealing immediately with a battery change in the TV remote and offering to bring ice. They patiently answered all my questions and directed me to a nearby 24/7 Duane Reade and deli. I got all wake-up calls on time and housekeeping didn't disturb.I would stay here again. It's definitely quieter and less crowded than other parts of the city.

Love the wood floors (no disgusting carpet!) :-)Staff are super helpful and made us feel very welcome.Advertised as a boutique hotel, but they need to do a little more on room quality to meet that claim.Would stay again for convenience to Wall StKudos to staff - they make it better than it is..

Not a bad location if you need to stay near Wall Street, but there are many significantly better options. The room is decent sized for New York, but it feels like a motel 6 that they have tried make appear a bit modern. While the room was clean, it had a very cheap and dingy feeling. I wouldnt stay there again unless I was very desperate.

We stayed here over the fourth of July weekend. We only booked it because our hostel closed down, but I'm glad we ended up here. It worked out cheaper than the hostel! It was easily accessible by taxi from the airport, being on the edge of Manhattan. When we arrived at 2pm, our room wasn't ready so we went for a walk. Wall street was just around the corner, and we managed to do a bit of sightseeing, and see Ground Zero before we headed back to the room. It was a great base for sightseeing. The room was lovely, clean and spacious (no view though). We found it hard to get the room to a comfortable temperature and the air con was quite loud at night. There was a mini bar (reasonably priced as mini bars go) and coffee available in the room (but no tea!). Breakfast was nice, but pretty much the same every morning. There was a quiet bar downstairs too. Staff were nice and helpful. They recommended some good places to eat nearby. I would stay here again.

Friendly and quiet for couples who want to find each other. Accessible through train from the aiport. Easy to move from - to any parts of NYC to those who want to acquaint themselves with NYC using public transport. However, be warned that breakfast is one and the same (not bad). It can be monotonous if you are staying for more than 3 days.

I stayed here for two nights while on business. The location was good as my meetings were at the World Financial Center. It was only a 15 minute walk. However, at night it is a bit quiet although I never felt unsafe. Can be quite hard to get a cab in front of the hotel although the hotel staff walked a block and flagged down a cab for me. I got a room with 2 Queen beds. It was gigantic. The bathroom was not fancy. There was tons of space in the room although they probably should repaint the ceilings as there was visible water damage. The room smelled a little damp. Overall the hotel wasn't impressive (the staff was). There are better choices in the area but the Eurostars is relatively affordable compared to others in the area.

We booked this hotel at the last minute. We were very impressed as soon as we walked in the door. Friendly and helpful staff. Our room was big with high ceilings. We made coffee each morning. We also had a few drinks at the bar. There are some cute restaurants in the area as well as a convenience store and Starbucks. We always felt safe being in the financial district (lots of security around), and it was also great to escape the craziness of Times Square etc.

Eurostars Wall Street Hotel is a great hotel for the price in NYC. We stayed there for four nights during a business trip. We received a room upgrade, so our room was spacious and had a large window looking down Front street. The towels were clean and the sheets were crisp and clean. The room was also quite clean, and very spacious for NYC. It was very quiet as well. The staff was pleasant and helpful. Access to the Subway was via the Wall Street 2-3 exit, which was about a 3 block walk to the hotel, so very easy access. The hotel is also close to the Seaport area, where we ate some good food and enjoyed looking at the large masted ships docked in the harbor. Easy access to things, but not in the fray, which was great... We would stay there again.

The level of customer service is sub standard. There seems to be the arrogance of the European waiter here. I have cashed Amex travelers checks throughout he world. Not here! Why, we do not have the software!!!!!! Fortunately this is the banking district and a bank is nearby.If you want convenience to meetings this works but it is overpriced and is not customer centric.

New York City, New York

review_body: I just got home yesterday from NYC and stayed at Eurostars Wall Street. This place was great! I was there on business and it was literally a 2 minute walk from where I had to be. There is a mall only a 5 minute walk that has everything you could possibly need at any time. There is a Starbucks on the next corner block, a pharmacy within 5 minutes of walking. You can even walk to Chinatown which I did!! Great location and the staff was amazing! The guys that work at the front desk are very knowledgeable and friendly! They will get you anywhere you need to go the best possible route. I checked out and 20 minutes later had to go back in to use their computer area and not only did they remember me, but they had no problem letting me use the computer area even though I was no longer a guest there! I always got a 'Good Morning' and a 'Hello' when coming or going. They don't have a continental breakfast but I didn't really need breakfast since I brought my own stuff to munch on. No room service, but again, with everything so close, that was also not a problem. There was a small fridge and microwave in the room that could be used if need be. Very clean and comfy room ~ bigger than some places that I stayed in previously. I would recommend this place highly!!

The location is ok depending on what you want to do. Not much going on in the financial district on the weekend, so quiet outside. There was a party in the hotel room nearby that was noisy. The party woke me up (1am getting kinda loud), but I think someone came up because the noise was less about 15 minutes later. There's a seaport closeby where you can take a water tour of the city and about a 15 minute walk to the harbor to catch a ferry to Ellis/Statue of Liberty. Subway stops are also close. There is some construction going on at the front of the hotel, so the cabbie couldn't find it right away. The people were nice and friendly. They can't call a cab, but one guy flagged a cab for me (Front Street has little traffic, so he had to go up a block). The bed, as one person mentioned, is a bit hard. I'd call the hotel "sparse". The tv worked and it was clean (not overly spotless, but not a dump). For the price, it was pretty good. Hotels around that area are expensive.

This is the type of place that you are afraid to let your feet touch the floor in. They don't even have real carpeting, it is some kind of burlap/velcro material that you stick to when you are walking. It's like something you would put on a makeshift porch of a trailer. The air conditioning doesn't work and the room is about 85 degrees right now. Yes, I am currently in it suffering all of it's horrors. Don't trust the pictures...I don't know how they made it look so nice online. And there is nothing cozy about it. It makes you wish you brought your own linens! In fact when I did a search on this hotel Google prefilled the words "bed bugs" after the name...I am not even going to click on it.

My BFF and I stayed here (one bdrm suite) for my 40th bd and it was WONDERFUL! The service was exceptional and our room was amazing. Apart from some renovations that were happening, there was absolutely nothing wrong with our stay here. Staying in this area is a more economical and quiet NYC experience, and this particular suite is a steal. Honorable mention goes to the delicious orange blossom scent that wafts thru out the entire hotel! Also, front desk staff (Taylor & Alex specifically) went above and beyond and we miss them terribly!

Don't let the facade and the state of the surrounding buildings shock you. There is still construction going on, but not as bad as elsewhere in the city. And the street itself is very quiet at night.I would not yet call it a 'luxury' boutique hotel, it still needs some work done.BUT: the rooms are very spacious (at least the executive guest room I was in), with high ceilings. The workstation is sufficiently spaced and there is an extremely comfortable office chair. The 'minimalistic' interior still has everything you need: flatscreen TV, microwave, fridge, coffeemaker, good assortment of snacks.(First time I have ever seen an 'intimacy kit' (condoms) and First Aid kit in a hotel room !)While some have commented that the beds are very hard, which is true, I appreciated that and found it to be just right.A MAJOR plus: free WiFi in the rooms (I really don't understand why most business hotels, including high priced ones, are still charging for it. These days it should be part of the room amenities.) Although the hotel has recently been renovated, the room already showed some wear and tear, including water damage on the bathroom ceiling and floor. But don't forget, this is a very old building.The lobby is modern, so is the bar area.The staff is very friendly and extremely helpfull.All in all a very good place and if they keep up the renovations it is well on it's way to become a true luxury boutique hotel.

I was put up here for one night having been "walked" by the hotel with which I had a reservation. First impressions not good as the receptionist was rather surly. The room was very poor indeed: tired decorations, a very uncomfortable bed with a pathetically thin matress and the sense that the furnishings had been bought for a completely different location. Bathroom in particular was rather grimy. To finish things off, the room eas very noisy with traffic sounds from early in the morning. Not in the least bit attractive or comfortable. There were two saving graces. First, the location is very, very central for Wall Street (although my taxi driver struggled to find it). Second, the self-service breakfast was good: nice room, reasonable choice and good coffee. So, if you want to have breakfast in a good location this would be a good bet. But ot so good if you like comfortable room and a good night's sleep.

The staff were great. All our requests were met promptly by very friendly staff.The 5 of us stayed in a Double 2 Queen bed room with a roll away. The room was huge, about 300sqft. There was enough space for all our luggage. However, the room do look worn and more hard work is needed to clean the room and the bathroom. I suggest they use bleach. I didn't like the feel of the rough carpet against my feet. The mattresses weren't great either, I felt the springs on all the beds especially the roll away.Very close to Wall Street with easy access to Staten Ferry. The nearest subway is only 5 minutes walk away and from there, only 10 minutes (at most) to Times Square. Only 10 minutes walk away to the bottom of Broadway where all the shops are.

Wow! Eurostars has far exceeded our expectations! Everything is just fabulous here. The decor is modern and trendy. There is a hip little bar near the lobby. Check in was a breeze. Our room is fabulous, clean, very roomy and a really comfy bed. Aside from all of that, the staff really sets this hotel apart. Lamont and Jose are so friendly and helpful. Suggestion after suggestion, directions and they were not waiting for a tip (even though we were happy to give them one) It is in the financial district, so there is not a lot going on, but for us it was perfect b/c it was a nice clean, safe area and it is nice and quiet for a good night's sleep. We will definitely stay here again!

kinzeesmom
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: My trip to new york became so much better because of the staff, they were very friendly and always offered help. I wear a headscarf and i expected staring but it was more than that, I faced hostile unwelcoming staring , and people clearly not wanting to help when we ask for directions. The rooms are new, very clean, the heating was not working, but later on someone fixed it for us. The exhaust fan in the bathroom didnt work but it wasnt a major thing. The location is great , close to 3 subway stations and to Wall street, there''s a lot of Cafes and Restaurants walking distance in the area. It wasnt difficult to sleep late night because the area becomes very quiet which is a good thing if you travel with babies or a couple looking to relax. There's a discounted parking close by, but still it wasnt cheap.

I stayed here because I could get a free night with my airline points. From the website it looked very modern and trendy. Upon arrival I was surprised at what I saw. The website pictures were obviously taken a couple years ago. The lobby was plain looking and the furniture worn. Our room was large and had a full kitchen, but the carpet was rough and stained. The bed was the hardest thing I have ever slept on in my life-talk about a quick way to ruin a vacation. The towels were also rougher than I have had in most hotels, and they didn't give us new ones after our first night (which we didn't realize until the following morning when we went to shower). The lounge was supposed to be open Monday through Friday, but when we went to have a drink Friday night we found the doors closed. It was fine for a free night, but I wouldn't stay there again.

The location was good for my meeting at the Exchange, however, this is definitely not a hotel for executives. My major complaints were the futon-style bed and no food service of any kind. After traveling for 6 hours and arriving at the hotel late at night, I ate peanuts for dinner! Also, I'm not sure why our company was charged $499 for a room here, when others are saying they were charged in the $200 range. You can get a room at the Ritz for $499, however, they were full the night I was in town. Next time the Ritz is unavailable, I'll stay at the Embassy Suites and take a cab.

We stayed there for my birthday in June and the room was very large for NYC standards. We had a large fully equipped kitchen and a nice size living room. We had two plasma tvs one in the living room and one in the bedroom which was very nice. The bathroom was clean and modern but the towels were small and not very soft. We had a buffet breakfast which was included in the price and it was fine with ceral toast muffins juice and scrambled eggs and bacon. All in all we enjoyed our stay and we thought it was very good valvue for the money. We enjoyed being so close to the South Street Seaport and the subway for uptown was two blocks away. We would stay in this hotel again.

Your taxi driver might not be able to find this place, so print out a map of the Financial District before you leave home. The rooms are very large by NY standards and include a fridge and microwave. The bathroom is big and modern. There is a seating area along with two double beds and extra room to spare. It's not a bad choice if you are in NY for business on and near Wall Street, otherwise I can't think of any reason to stay in this part of NY. Unfortunately, the biggest drawback is the noise from the street below. The street is not that busy, but you can hear noise from delivery and garbage trucks below.

This was a real cool hotel right in the middle of the Financial District. Very nice rooms and furniture, very modern and big, too. Very pleasant to stay and very nice employees helping with anything you need. And that's at good rates. Good connections to subway, short walking distances to south pier, battery park, ground zero etc.

I stayed here for one night, primarily because of its location near Wall St. Small lobby, friendly and attentive staff. The ambiance approached that of a boutique hotel but the facilities fell short of the amenities that you expect in such a hotel. The room was large with a comfortable armchair. Didn't like the futon-style mattress (my days of sleeping on a futon mattress were over a long time ago). No exercise facility on site and the wireless service was spotty (a colleague I was traveling with also experienced less than optimal wireless). Overall, for one night, the hotel was a good choice, primarily because of its location near my meeting near Wall St. And the price was very good ($229). But i wouldn't want to spend more than one night here. I'd prefer a full service hotel or a true boutique hotel.

In an effort to save my multi-national bank some money, I decided to stay here on my last business trip to New York. This hotels is passable, but if you're an executuve type, you're not going to like it. This hotel used to be called the Exchange Hotel (see Trip Advisor reviews accordingly). The staff was fine. The room was a bit odd, synthetic carpet tiles were old and used, and the bed (like other reviewers comments) was a single mattress on a "trend" bedframe. The mattress was next to sleeping on a rock (and I don't complain, so if I am writing this review, it means I actually took the time to care and forewarn you). The hotel itself if slightly run down, although if you visit the Eurostars site, they lead to you to believe that you're staying at an upscale "boutique" hotel - this is by all means a stretch. During my three day stay, the lobby lounge was uninviting with it's blaring rap (yep, rap) music. The morning free breakfast was OK, but nothing great. The location us great if you're working on Wall Street or in the near vicinity. Otherwise, Gild Hall, the Hilton Millenium are better business travel choices.

The hotel is located in the heart of the financial and Seaport district. The hotel was tastefully appointed and had a great breakfast buffet. The staff was exceptional, especially Arturo Guerra at the Front Desk.

Saratoga Springs, New York

review_body: Great location. The perfect location to see NYC. Very quiet at the weekend. Open top tour bus is the best way to travel because of value for money. City Sights NY was perfect. There is a bus stop a stone's throw from the hotel and the tube is one street up. The hotel breakfast didn't look great so we just ate out around. This wasn't a problem though as there are tons of yummy diners and cafes nearby. A&F is only down the road and tons of lovely restaurants too in a cobled street waterside area. Feels very european and classy (a nice contract from the brashness of time square).The breakfast was the only disappointing thing about the hotel and we didn't eat it (may have been better than it looked). I would recommend going room only though. The prices are incredible, given the size of the room and quality of the hotel. Very stylish and boutique feel.We were upgraded. It was my friends 30th. We stayed in room 805. Surely the best room in the hotel. As big as my sitting room and lounge put together!! I though NYC rooms were sposed to be small?!!!!?? Two massive double beds, a leather couch, a desk area. Bathroom didn't really match up with the 5 star standard of the room but it was pleasant and clean and well appointed.Staff were friendly but left you to be independant. Perfect! Free internet and computer = a definate plus. We booked through Late rooms and paid 100-150 pounds a night. 50-70 each. What a bargain!!!I would definately go back to Eurostars when in NYC. I don't even think the big hotels (where you pay 4 times as much) would come close to comparing in value for money, location and style.Book this now or you'll regret it. Prices are jumping up week after week.

We spent a weekend at the end of march there and really enjoyed the central location just off wall st and near to the world trade center site. The staff was very helpful, the room was spacious and well furnished. They even have a computer for guest's access to the internet. The lounge bar was closed over the weekend, that was not a problem for us, since the seaport south and a lot of other bars were nearby, also wendys and burger king. Only parking in the nearby garage was a bit expensive at 30$ per night! By the way: the 21st century is still a very good place to shop for shoes and designer clothes!
